node.text:
Consulting winemaker @jean_hoefliger discusses how he picks new projects, the potential of Texas wine and what issues the wine industry will need to address in the future.

.
.
.
.
#winespectator #wine #wsstraighttalk

node.text:
The newly appointed winemaker at @burgesscellars talks about diversity in the industry, regenerative farming, her love of old Napa and more…

#wsstraighttalk #winespectator #wine #NapaValley

node.text: The happiest hours are spent with INDOGGO® flavored gin! Brought to you by Snoop Dogg, INDOGGO® is the ultimate remix of seven premium botanicals and all-natural strawberry flavor. Head to @indoggogin's website to purchase a bottle and to check out their Snoop approved cocktail recipes.  Cocktail Pictured: The Remix  #INDOGGO® is a flavored gin #RemixYourGin #sponsored

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on July 22, 2021. May be a closeup.

node.text:
Splish splash, anyone want a wine bath? ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Jimmy Hayes, our #WSfeaturedphotographer for July, captured this shot during remontage. Remontage is the French term for the process of pumping red wine up from the bottom of the tank and splashing it over the top of the fermenting must; the purpose is to submerge the skins so that carbon dioxide is pushed to the surface of the must and released.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
If you like this image, be sure to check out Hayes' book of photography, "Veritas" which releases in September via @CameronBooks and @AbramsBooks.⁠ Click the link.bio for more.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @toomanyjimmys⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #winerywork

node.text:
Australian wine has it all. While benchmark estates maintain their trademark style and high quality from vintage to vintage, a spirit of innovation across this vast continent’s many winegrowing areas is inspiring greater freshness and more complex aromatics. Beyond the mass-produced fruity Shirazes and straightforward Chardonnays, there’s so much more to discover, from bold, concentrated reds to vibrant, elegant whites.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio to read senior editor MaryAnn Worobiec’s recent tasting report, including analysis of the current market for Australian wine, notable brands new to or once again available in the United States, plus her scores and tasting notes for more than 425 recommended wines.⁠⁠
⁠⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSeducate #Australianwine #winemaps

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator on July 21, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and people standing.

node.text:
After an 11-minute space flight on the Blue Origin New Shepard rocket that took him 66.5 miles above the earth, @jeffbezos tried to improve life on the planet below, announcing a $100 million award to Spanish chef and humanitarian @chefjoseandres, co-founder of World Central Kitchen. Andrés says he will use the money to expand the mission of the nonprofit @wckitchen, which helps feed and support people in disaster-stricken areas around the world, to also fight systemic hunger.⁠
⁠
"I'm really grateful for this award, and the incredible support from Jeff and the entire Bezos family," said Andrés. "World Central Kitchen was born from the simple idea that food has the power to create a better world. A plate of food is a plate of hope. It's the fastest way to rebuild lives and communities."⁠
⁠
⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Wine Spectator on July 20, 2021 tagging @faviawines, and @andy.erickson. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Our #WSfeaturedphotographer series for July continues with this image of winemaker Andy Erickson checking on his wines aging in barrel underneath his home in Coombsville.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Winemaking is certainly romantic, but it's also a steady drumbeat of work, much of which is solitary in nature. That's why we asked photographer Jimmy Hayes to share some of his images using the theme of 'winery work'.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠Click the linkin.bio for more on Hayes' book of photography, "Veritas", releasing this September via @CameronBooks and @AbramsBooks.⁠ ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
 ⁠⁠
📸: @toomanyjimmys⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSfeaturedphotographer #winephotography #winerywork

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Wine Spectator in Wine Spectator. May be an image of 1 person and bottle.

node.text:
Decanting sure looks swanky. But it performs a vital function too - it's meant to help wines to show their best once they hit your glass.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
So, which wines need it? When should you do it? And how?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It always helps to know the basics. Click the linkin.bio for our Wine 101 article and video on decanting your wine.⁠⁠
⁠⁠.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
. ⁠⁠
📸: @AlinaTyulyu⁠⁠
⁠⁠
#winespectator #wine #WSeducate #WSlifestyle #decanting

node.text:
What wine grape do you think of when you see this?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This popular red grape originated in Burgundy but has spread across the New World. Like its white Burgundian counterpart Chardonnay, Pinot Noir is early-budding, early-ripening and thin-skinned. The sites where it tends to thrive can experience tough growing conditions, which lead to more rigorous fruit selection and lower yields. This is one of the reasons that high-quality Pinot Noir often carries a higher price tag than other wines.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for our complete Know Your Grapes Series, and keep an eye out for our annual California Pinot Noir report coming soon...!⁠⁠
.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠

node.text:
Canned wine continues to be one of the most rapidly growing wine categories in the United States. Volume sales in Nielsen-tracked channels reached $253 million in the 52 weeks ending March 20, 2021, up 62 percent over the previous 12 months.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As the category grows, many winemakers are trying to raise the bar for what consumers expect from canned wine. In the past, the message was simple: You can take it with you.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
But these vintners believe their canned wines offer a lot more. Will wine drinkers hear their message⁠?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for the full report along with scores and reviews for 16 newly released canned wines.⁠⁠
⁠.⁠⁠

node.text:
For #ThrowbackThursday, we are going back to Oakville in 1967. That's Robert Mondavi checking on a load of Chenin Blanc grapes purchased from the MacDonald family's plot of vines in the famed To Kalon vineyard.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
These days, brothers Alex and Graeme MacDonald still sell a majority of their fruit to the Robert Mondavi winery next door. But they also keep a small portion of fruit from vines planted in 1954 to make just a few hundred cases of Cabernet Sauvignon under their own eponymous label - and it's one of the best Cabernets in Napa Valley today.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Click the linkin.bio for more on this little bit of Napa Valley wine history.⁠⁠
.⁠⁠

node.text:
California Chardonnay is decisively moving away from the days when big, buttery and oaky versions dominated the upper echelon of the market. The new generation of wines coming on the scene, defined by gentler fermentations and a lighter use of oak, is fostering an explosion of quality across the Golden State.⁠
⁠
Senior editor Kim Marcus's annual tasting report is out now in our current July 31 issue. He finds high quality across the board in both the successful 2018 and 2019 vintages. Get his scores and tasting notes for top wines, smart buys and value picks by clicking the linkin.bio...!⁠
⁠⁠.⁠
.⁠

node.text:
Lab work may not be glamorous, but it is required in wine making.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This month's #WSfeaturedphotographer series continues with images from Jimmy Hayes and the theme of winery work. Here, Artie Johnson checks the brix on a lot of old vine Carignan that went into his first vintage under the Le Artishasic label.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Brix is a measurement used to calculate an approximate potential alcohol content in the eventual wine and it's one of the many measurements winemakers use when performing their craft.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Hayes' book of photography, "Veritas" releases in September via @CameronBooks and @AbramsBooks.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸: @toomanyjimmys⁠⁠

node.text:
What wine grape do you think of when you see this?⁠
⁠
Hint: this white grape takes its name from a village in the Mâconnais region of Burgundy in France. It remains widely grown there today, but the variety became so popular in the 1970s that for a time it became nearly synonymous with "white wine" in the U.S. Today, almost every wine-producing region in the world grows It.⁠..⁠
⁠⁠
It’s Chardonnay, an early-budding and early-ripening variety that is relatively easy to grow, explaining its attractiveness to winemakers. The best soils for its vines are limestone, chalk and calcareous clay. The main appeal of Chardonnay lies in its versatility: its ability to translate terroir, or a sense of where it's grown. ⁠
⁠
Click the linkin.bio for more on Chardonnay and all the major wine grapes via our Know Your Grapes series. And don’t forget to check out our annual report on California Chardonnay in the current July 31 issue of Wine Spectator!⁠
